Leong (F) }} [[Malay styles and titles|Tun]] '''Leong Yew Koh''' ({{zh|t=|s=梁宇皋|p=Liáng Yǔgāo|j=Leung1 Yau3 Koh5}}; 22 August 1888 – 12 January 1963){{cite web|url=http://www.tytmelaka.gov.my/versionBI/index.php/2012-09-24-01-09-13/the-first-president-of-malacca|title=The First President of Malacca|date=2012-09-24|accessdate=2016-06-17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812074428/http://www.tytmelaka.gov.my/versionBI/index.php/2012-09-24-01-09-13/the-first-president-of-Malacca|archivedate=2016-08-12}} was the first Governor of [[Malacca]] since independence. ==Background== Born in Salak Utara, [[Sungai Siput]], [[Perak]] on 22 August 1888, Leong was the son of Leong Yew Teen, who was responsible in developing Salak Utara, Perak. He went to [[Guangzhou|Canton]], [[China]], for his early education. At age 13, he came back to [[British Malaya|Malaya]] from China and studied in [[Anglo-Chinese School|Anglo-Chinese School Ipoh]] and [[St Xavier's Institution]], [[Penang]]. 1906, at age 16, he joined [[Tongmenghui|Tongmenghui Singapore]]. He went to the University of London in 1908, studying economics, sociology, political science and law. He graduated in 1912 with an [[Bachelor of Laws|LLB]]. ==Legal career== He was called to the bar in 1920 and served as an advocate and solicitor in the Federated Malay States (FMS) and was also a member of the FMS Bar Committee until his resignation in 1932.[http://www.asiawind.com/forums/read.php?f=4&i=4302&t=4302]Unititled notice, The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser (1884-1942), 20 July 1932, Page 12 ==Political career== On 27 February 1949, [[Tan Cheng Lock|Tun Tan Cheng Lock]] founded the [[Malaysian Chinese Association|Malayan Chinese Association]] (MCA) along with Leong Yew Koh and [[H.S. Lee|Colonel H. S. Lee]]. He was the first Secretary-General of MCA.{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiandigest.com/features/77922-malaysian-road-names-who-is-who.html|title=Malaysian Road Names: Who's Who?|date=18 June 2013|work=Malaysian Digest|accessdate=2018-02-14}} He was appointed as the Yang Dipertua Negeri of Melaka on 31 August 1957, and served until 30 August 1959. In 1958, he was awarded a federal title of Tun, bestowed by DYMM Seri Paduka Baginda Yang DiPertuan Agung of Malaya. In 1959, he was appointed as Justice Minister of Malaya. He died on 12 January 1963.{{cite web|url=http://www2.arkib.gov.my/hids/print.php?type=A&item_id=5422|title=Tun Leong Yew Koh Meninggal Dunia|date=2011-11-14|accessdate=2018-02-14}} He was the first Chinese to be appointed as the Yang di-Pertua Negeri in any of the Malaysian States.{{cite web|url=https://archive.is/u04x6|title=First Malacca Governor is Leong Yew Koh. But today even government office boy’s job denied to Indian poor: Racist UMNO Agenda.|publisher=[[Human Rights Party Malaysia]]|date=2012-04-06|accessdate=2018-02-14|via=[[archive.is]]}} As of 2015, he is the only Chinese to be appointed as the Yang di-Pertua Negeri in any of the Malaysian States. ==Honour== ===Honour of Malaya=== *{{flagu|Malaya}} : Grand Commander of the [[Order of the Defender of the Realm]] (S.M.N.) (1958){{cite web |url=http://www.istiadat.gov.my/v8/images/stories/1958.pdf|title=Senarai Penuh Penerima Darjah Kebesaran, Bintang dan Pingat Persekutuan Tahun 1958.}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-new|creation}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Yang di-Pertua Negeri of Malacca]]|years=1957–1959}} {{s-aft|after=[[Abdul Malek Yusuf]]}} {{end}} {{First Rahman cabinet}} {{Second Rahman cabinet}} {{Grand Commander of the Order of the Defender of the Realm}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1888 births]] [[Category:Malaysian Roman Catholics]] [[Category:1963 deaths]] [[Category:People from Perak]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Members of the Dewan Negara]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Cantonese descent]] [[Category:Malaysian Chinese Association politicians]] [[Category:British Malaya lawyers]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of London]] [[Category:Yang di-Pertua Negeri of Melaka]] [[Category:Government ministers of Malaysia]] [[Category:Grand Commanders of the Order of the Defender of the Realm]] [[Category:Health ministers of Malaysia]] [[Category:Justice ministers of Malaysia]]

'''Medicus Mundi International (MMI)''' is a Network of public interest organisations working in the field of international health cooperation and advocacy. The Network members fight global poverty by promoting access to health and health care as a fundamental human right (“Health for All”). The Network aims at enhancing the quality and effectiveness of the work of its members and their partners through sharing know-how and joining forces. Key fields of joint activity include global health policy and governance (MMI is an organization in official relations with the World Health Organization) and the improvement of legitimacy, relevance and effectiveness of international health cooperation.
==Network Members== The MMI Network has the following member organisations: *[http://www.africachap.org/x5/ Africa Christian Health Associations Platform, ACHAP], Kenya *[http://www.medeor.de/ action medeor], Germany *[http://amces-benin.org/ AMCES], Benin *[http://www.cwgh.co.zw/ Community Working Group on Health], Zimbabwe *[[Cordaid]], The Netherlands *[http://www.cuamm.org/ Doctors with Africa CUAMM], Italy *[http://epnetwork.org/ Ecumenical Pharmaceutical Network EPN], Kenya *[http://www.emergenzasorrisi.it/ Emergenza Sorrisi], Italy *[http://www.easp.es/ Escuela Andaluza de Salud Pública EASP], Spain *[[Health Poverty Action]], United Kingdom *[https://www.itg.be/ Institute of Tropical Medicine Antwerp], Belgium *[http://www.iplussolutions.org/ i+solutions], The Netherlands *[http://www.medico.de/en/ Medico international], Germany *[https://www.medicswithoutvacation.be/ Medics without Vacation], Belgium *[http://www.medicusmundi.it/ Medicus Mundi Italy] *[http://www.medicusmundi.ch Medicus Mundi Switzerland, Network Health for All] *[http://www.medicusmundi.es/ Medicus Mundi Spain] *[http://www.memisa.be/ Memisa], Belgium *[http://www.medicus.amp.edu.pl/ Redemptoris Missio, Medicus Mundi Poland] *[http://www.wemos.nl Wemos Foundation], The Netherlands

The '''Myanmar Eye Care Project''' ('''MECP''') is focused on improving the delivery of critical [[Optometry|eye care]] services to at-risk populations in [[Myanmar]]. Founded in 2002 and staffed entirely by [[Ophthalmology|ophthalmologists]], it aims to end [[blindness]] in Myanmar. Myanmar is one of the poorest countries in [[Southeast Asia]] and has the highest rate of blindness in the world. Working with partners and a network of providers, MECP operates clinics that provide routine eye care, acute treatment, and surgeries to Myanmar’s poor rural populations. MECP also builds eye care infrastructure in rural communities, trains indigenous physicians and nursing staff, and provides equipment.
==History== In early 2002, a resident of Sydney, Australia, and former refugee from Myanmar asked Sydney-based ophthalmologist Dr Geoffrey Cohn [[Order of Australia|OAM]]<ref name="OAMcitation">{{cite web|title=Governer-General Honours List|url=https://www.gg.gov.au/sites/default/files/files/honours/ad/ad2010/Media%20Notes%20OAM%20(A-E)%20(final).pdf|website=Governer-General Honours List|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> to consider setting up an eye care project in Myanmar. Cohn had previously worked ''[[pro bono]]'' in [[Bali]], in the development of eye care projects in [[Indonesia]] in 1989 with Yayasan Kemanusiaan Indonesia (also known as The John Fawcett Foundation),<ref name="JF">{{cite web|title=the John Fawcett Organisation|url=http://johnfawcett.org/|website=The John Fawcett Organisation|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> in [[Papua New Guinea]] from 1993 to 2001 for the Church Medical Council of Papua New Guinea, and in [[Cambodia]] from 1998 to 1999 with [[HelpAge International]].<ref name="HelpAge">{{cite web|title=HelpAge International|url=http://www.helpage.org/tags/cambodia/|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
With the support of U Lakkhana, Chief Abbot of the [[The Wachet Jivitadana Sangha Hospital#Kyaswa Monastery and Sayadaw U Lakkhana|Kyaswa Monastery]], and with the help of local project co-coordinators, members of the monastery community and many volunteers, MECP began treating patients in [[The Wachet Jivitadana Sangha Hospital]] by late 2002.<ref name="HollowsLecture">{{cite web|url=http://ranzcoabstracts.com/abstract/teaching-and-learning-in-the-resource-poor-world/|title=Hollows Lecture, RANZCO Congress, Perth, 2017.|website=RANZCO abstracts|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
[[File:DawPhuySinnMon.jpg|thumb|A doctor examining patients on the morning following surgery]] Following this, a second project was established in a monastery hospital on the slopes of [[Mount Popa]] in 2003.<ref name="MtPopa">{{cite journal|last1=Nemet|first1=Arie|last2=Nemet|first2=Pinhas|last3=Cohn|first3=Geoffrey|last4=Sutton|first4=Gina|last5=Sutton|first5=Gerald|last6=Rawson|first6=Richard|title=Causes of blindness in rural Myanmar (Burma): Mount Popa Taung-Kalat Blindness Prevention Project|journal=Clinical Ophthalmology|date=2009|volume=3|pages=413-421}}</ref> The current national project co-ordinator and project developer of MECP for the past ten years, Daw Phyu Sinn Mon,<ref name="IPABanalysis">{{cite book|last1=Pokharel|first1=Gopal|last2=Khanna|first2=Rohit|title=Prevention of Blindness in Myanmar: Situation Analysis and Strategy for Change|date=2013|url=https://www.iapb.org/wp-content/uploads/Prevention-of-Blindness-in-Myanmar_Situational-Analysis-Strategy-for-Change_0.pdf}}</ref> initially trained as an ophthalmic technician at the Mount Popa-Taung-Kalat centre in 2003.
At the request of U Nayaka, Chief Abbot of Phaung Daw Oo Monastery, another eye care project was started within his monastery at the foot of Mandalay Hills in 2004. In the following years, the service consulted with hundreds of thousands of outpatients, performed tens of thousands of free or low cost eye operations and trained many mid-level ophthalmic technicians (MLOT).<ref name="HollowsLecture" /> The project has continued to grow with the help of donations and visiting teams of eye surgeons, technicians and support staff from Australia, New Zealand, Great Britain, Nepal, and the United States of America.<ref name="HollowsLecture" />
The project has also been responsible for the introduction of subspecialty training of local ophthalmologists in [[vitreoretinal surgery]], glaucoma and corneal specialties.<ref name="HollowsLecture" /> In 2010, Sydney-based vitreoretinal surgeon Dr H. Kwon Kang introduced vitreoretinal surgery teaching and services to The Wachet Jivitadana Sangha Hospital.<ref name="Eye2Eye">{{cite book|last1=Imam|first1=Maheen|title=Eye2Eye|date=2017|publisher=Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Ophthalmologists|url=https://ranzco.edu/ArticleDocuments/226/ArticleDocuments/226/Spring%202017%20Eye2Eye.pdf.aspx?Embed=Y|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="NewLight">{{cite news|last1=Tun|first1=Mya|title=Good Samaritans working on Christmas Holidays for eye patients in Sagaing Hills|url=http://www.globalnewlightofmyanmar.com/good-samaritans-working-on-christmas-holidays-for-eye-patients-in-sagaing-hills/|accessdate=19 December 2017|work=Global New Light of Mynamar|date=2015}}</ref> In 2015, Prof. Gerard Sutton (Professor of [[Corneal]] and [[Refractive]] Surgery) and a team from the New South Wales [[Lions Eye Bank]] worked with Prof. Daw Yee Yee Aung (Professor of Ophthalmology, Mandalay Eye and Ear Hospital) to establish the Mandalay Eye Bank.<ref name="Eye2Eye" /><ref name="EyeBankJournal">{{cite journal|last1=Au|first1=Yee Yee|last2=Sutton|first2=Gerard|last3=Vaddavalli|first3=Pravin|last4=Varma|first4=Meghna|last5=Fernandes|first5=Merle|last6=Devashyam|first6=Raj|last7=Treloggan|first7=Jane|last8=Cooper|first8=Simon|last9=Petsoglou|first9=Con|last10=Machin|first10=Heather|last11=Hodge|first11=Chris|title=Eye Banking in Myanmar: A Review of Services and the Role of International Non-profit Community Based Organizations Transitioning Mandalay Eye Bank Towards Self-Sufficiency|journal=International journal of eye banking|date=2017|volume=5|issue=2|url=http://eyebankingjournal.org/article/eye-banking-myanmar-review-services-role-international-non-profit-community-based-organizations-transitioning-mandalay-eye-bank-towards-self-sufficiency/}}</ref> From 2014 to 2016, paediatric ophthalmologist and academic Dr Judith Newman has also assisted Mandalay Eye and Ear Hospital in training paediatric ophthalmology.<ref name="Eye2Eye" />
==Ongoing projects== As of December 2017, the MECP has contributed to eleven projects, nine of which are currently running throughout Myanmar.<ref name="MThrosbyMay2017">{{cite news|last1=Throsby|first1=Margaret|title=Interview with Dr Geoffrey Cohn|work=Radio Interview|agency=ABC Classic FM, Breakfast show|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=May 2017}}</ref> Several outreach projects and charity programs are also being supported by MECP.<ref name="IPABanalysis" /> The MECP aims to provide cataract operations either free of cost or at significantly reduced cost and also aims that all visiting ophthalmologists have some university-affiliated teaching experience.<ref name="IPABanalysis" />
===Eye service at the Wachet Jivitadana Sangha Hospital=== This service was the original pilot project and continues to function as the principal teaching centre. It is one hour southwest of Mandalay.<ref name="AustDoc">{{cite journal|last1=Adler|first1=Paul|title=Eye-opener|journal=Australian Doctor|date=2012|volume=March|url=https://doctours.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/media_AusDoc_NewsReview_Mar12.pdf}}</ref>
===Mandalay Eye Bank=== Responsibility was handed to the MECP and Mandalay Eye and Ear Hospital by former Minister for Health, Prof. [[Pe The Khin]]. The Eye Bank serves as a repository for donated corneas, which may be stored and transplanted into patients with severe corneal disease. The MECP has facilitated technical training (from Sydney Eye Bank Technician Raj Devashayam) to harvest, assess and store corneas as well as surgical training (from Prof. Gerard Sutton) to perform and optimize [[corneal transplantation]].<ref name="EyeBankJournal" />
===Phaung Daw Oo Monastery, Mandalay=== Commencing in 2003, the MECP has provided equipment for the Eye service, trained many ophthalmic technicians and has recruited two Mandalay surgeons to serve this centre. The centre has become largely self-sufficient with MECP input needed only for equipment maintenance and replacement.<ref name="PhaungDawOo">{{cite web|title=Phaung Daw Oo School Free Charged Specialist Clinic|url=https://www.findhealthclinics.com/MM/Mandalay/1445297609106784/Phaung-Daw-Oo-School-Free-Charged-Specialist-Clinic|website=Find Health Clinics|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
===Yangon Jivitadana Sangha Hospital=== The centre dates initiatives back to the 1940s; however, the eye service commenced in 2012. The MECP has provided equipment and support, which allows more than twenty Yangon eye surgeons to operate in their spare time. MECP sponsors approximately 3,000 free cataract operations per year.<ref name="YangonJivitadana">{{cite web|title=Yangon Jivitadana Sangha Hospital|url=http://www.jivitahospital.org/english/medical_treatment.html|website=Jivitadana Sangha Hospital|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
===North Okkalapa General Hospital=== The MECP has significantly contributed to the surgical resident teaching program at the [[North Okkalapa General Hospital]]. This includes funding for teaching, teaching accessories, operating microscopes, lasers and other equipment. The centre now performs up to 2,400 free or subsidised cataract operations per year and provides training for ophthalmologists in residency.
===Thiri Dagon Monastery=== Located in Northeast [[Yangon]] in a highly flood-prone area, the MECP provides ophthalmic technicians and has facilitated two volunteer surgeons to service the area. The centre performs 1,500 free or subsidised cataract operations per year.<ref name="MThrosbyMay2017" />
===Phyar Pone=== In the wake of [[Cyclone Nargis]] in 2008, the MECP initially established two eye services, which merged into one to serve the people of the [[Ayeyarwady Region]]. The service employs ophthalmic technicians and ophthalmologists to perform 1,200 cataract operations per year.
===Mandalay Eye and Ear Hospital=== The MECP facilitated the donation of 1000 cataract operations in 2013, as well as the donation of specialist equipment. The MECP also provides ongoing support and teaching as required.<ref name="IPABanalysis" /><ref name="NewLight" />
===Hmawbi Monastery=== Requested by U Say Keinda, Chief Abbot of Hmawbi Monastery, the MECP established the service and has employed ophthalmic technicians, provided equipment and arranged for visiting ophthalmologists to service the area. The centre is now independent of MECP.
===Htee Saung Eye Hospital=== Serving as the principle training and development centre for ophthalmic technicians for the MECP, the hospital is the largest service under the governance of the MECP.<ref name="NewLight" /><ref name="tipitaka website">{{cite web|title=Tipitaka|url=http://www.shweyatutipieyehospital.org/|website=Tipitaka Website|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> This service employs up to four eye surgeons from Nepal and Laos and frequently accommodates teams of visiting eye surgeons from New Zealand, Australia, Thailand, China and the United States. In 2017, this service is expected to perform over 27,000 free cataract operations.
===Pyin Cee Monastery Eye Hospital=== Created in 2015, the MECP has provided equipment for the centre, trained ophthalmic technicians and has currently recruited one surgeon to serve this centre. The centre performs approximately 2,000 cataract operations per year.<ref name="MThrosbyMay2011">{{cite news|last1=Throsby|first1=Margaret|title=Interview with Dr Geoffrey Cohn|work=Radio Interview|agency=ABC Radio National|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2011}}</ref>
==Related organisations== * Cambodia Eye Care Project * Andhra Pradesh Eye Care Project
== References ==

[[File:140926-F-KB808-065 (15241173118).jpg|thumb|300px|Troops bound for Monrovia, Liberia board a transport aircraft (September 2014)]] '''Operation United Assistance''' is a 2014 [[United States military]] mission to help combat the [[Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa]], including the [[Ebola virus epidemic in Liberia|part of the epidemic occurring in Liberia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123440|title=Obama Activates Reserves for Operation United Assistance|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2014}} The [[101st Airborne Division]] headquarters was responsible for leading the mission.{{cn|date=December 2016}} == History == [[File:President Announces Ebola Plan 140917-F-BX142-240.webm|thumb|[[Barack Obama]] calls [[Ebola]] a national security priority and announces the US will establish a military command center in Liberia. [[United States Department of Defense]] video, September 17, 2014]] The [[United States Africa Command]], working through [[United States Army Africa]], has designated the [[Responses to the Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa#United States|Army's response to the Ebola epidemic]] as Operation United Assistance.{{cite web|url=http://www.africom.mil/operation-united-assistance|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014115649/http://www.africom.mil/operation-united-assistance|archivedate=14 October 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014|title=Operation United Assistance|work=|publisher=[[United States Africa Command]]}} Up to 4,000 [[U.S. Army]] troops are planned as part of an aid mission there, starting September 2014. Initially, the overall plan was to build 17 hospitals around the country of Liberia, each with 100-bed capacity.{{cite web|url=http://www.africom.mil/newsroom/article/23757/101st-airborne-soldiers-head-to-liberia-in-support-of-usaid|title=01st Airborne Soldiers head to Liberia in support of USAID|author=Maj. Dale Greer|date=20 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2014}} However, in late November 2014 this was reduced to 10 treatment centers with 50 beds each.[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/11/18/ebola-us-military-clinics-usaid/19233583/ U.S. military will build fewer Ebola clinics in Liberia] By early January 2015, 8 out of 10 centers were completed.[http://www.elpasotimes.com/news/ci_27300882/mission-liberia-has-been-huge-success-story-fort Mission to Liberia has been a 'huge success story,' Fort Bliss officer says] This type of hospital is called an [[Ebola Treatment Unit]] or ETU for short.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/us-liberia-open-treatment-center-for-health-workers/2512604.html|title=US, Liberia Open 1st Ebola Treatment Unit for Health Workers|work=VOA|accessdate=24 November 2014}} The military is also working with [[USAID]]. A 25-bed hospital planned for health workers staffed by U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps officers was opened November 7, 2014 near Monrovia. === Deployment === [[File:Reporters Briefed on Ebola Response 141008-N-JD259-001.webm|thumb|General David Rodriguez briefs reporters on Operation United Assistance, October 8, 2014]] By the end of September 2014 150 military personnel were helping USAID in the capital, Monrovia.{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123289|title=Operation United Assistance Helps in Liberian Ebola Fight|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2014}} Special isolation units for the [[C-17 Globemaster]] aircraft are being worked on in late 2014 to support medical evacuation of personnel should they be infected.{{cite web|url=http://www.armytimes.com/article/20141024/NEWS04/310240059/Isolation-pods-will-carry-troops-they-get-Ebola|title=Isolation pods will carry troops if they get Ebola|work=Army Times|accessdate=24 November 2014}} The current evacuation aircraft can only carry one patient at time, while the isolation unit is being designed to support up to 15. By early October there about 400 troops were in Liberia.{{cite web|url=http://www.13wmaz.com/story/news/nation/2014/10/11/training-protocols-reduce-ebola-risk-for-us-troops/17098687/|title=Training, protocols reduce Ebola risk for U.S. troops|author=Jim Michaels, USA TODAY|date=11 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2014}} This included soldiers from an Engineering Battalion, to help construct buildings for the operation.{{cite web|url=http://www.army.mil/article/136166/|title=15th Engineer Battalion deploys Soldiers in fight against Ebola|author=1st Lt. James Vidal, 15th Engineer Battalion Public Affairs Representative|date=17 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2014}} Initial work included transporting supplies to Liberia, and scouting out sites to build the treatment centers.[http://www.usaraf.army.mil/NEWS/NEWS_140923_eb1.html First shipment of the ramped-up U.S. military response to Ebola arrives in Liberia] By December 2014, there were three thousand servicemembers deployed for the operation; by February 2015, the number of servicemembers dropped to around thirteen hundred.{{cite news |last=Zoroya |first=Gregg |title=Military Ebola mission in Liberia coming to an end |url=http://www.militarytimes.com/story/military/pentagon/2015/02/04/military-ebola-mission-in-liberia-coming-to-an-end/22888079/ |newspaper=Military Times |publisher=Gannett |date=4 February 2015 |access-date=3 April 2015 }} In early April 2015, [[48th Chemical Brigade (United States)|48th Chemical Biological Radiological Nuclear Brigade]] deployed to Liberia to oversee the draw down of the operation.{{cite news |author=Chi Troung |title=48th CBRN Brigade uncases colors in Liberia |url=http://www.forthoodsentinel.com/story.php?id=15508 |newspaper=Fort Hood Sentinel |date=2 April 2015 |access-date=3 April 2015}} ==Monrovia Medical Unit== [[File:Monrovia Medical Unit October 8 2014.jpg|thumb|300px|The 25-bed Monrovia Medical Unit was constructed for health care workers supporting Operation United Assistance.]] The Monrovia Medical Unit is a 25-bed field hospital for local health care workers, that opened in November 2014 in Liberia in response to the Ebola epidemic there.[http://allafrica.com/stories/201411261146.html Liberia: Monrovia Medical Unit Aids Health Care Workers in Ebola Fight] Hundreds of health workers from Liberia and West Africa have died from the disease, and it is hoped the hospital will be an encouragement to volunteers. By October 2014 construction of the buildings for one 25-bed hospital was finished, called the ''Monrovia Medical Unit''.(1) [http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123434 Pentagon Spokesman Notes Operation United Assistance Progress]
(2) [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/11/05/ebola-americans-military-treatment-public-health-service/18538273/ U.S. uniformed officers to treat Ebola patients in Liberia] The plan was for US. Public Health Service officers to take care of Ebola-infected health care workers at the 25-bed facility.{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/policy/international/220996-americans-will-staff-liberian-ebola-hospital|title=US personnel will staff Liberian Ebola hospital|author=Kristina Wong|work=TheHill|accessdate=24 November 2014}} The staff was to come from members of the [[United States Public Health Service Commissioned Corps|U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/11/05/ebola-americans-military-treatment-public-health-service/18538273/|title=U.S. uniformed officers to treat Ebola patients in Liberia|author=Gregg Zoroya, USA TODAY|date=5 November 2014|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2014}} By October 19, it was reported that 223 health care workers had cases of Ebola in Liberia, and 103 of them had died.{{cite web|url=http://www.mohsw.gov.lr/documents/SITRep%20157%20Oct%2019th,%202014.pdf|title=Liberia Ebola SitRep no. 157 |accessdate=22 October 2014| date= 22 October 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/137091/1/roadmapsitrep22Oct2014_eng.pdf |accessdate=22 Oct 2014 |title=Ebola Response Roadmap Situation Report |date=22 Oct 2014 |author=WHO |work=who.int}} On 7 November 2014, a new air-conditioned 25-bed hospital was opened for West African health care workers. ==Precautions and quarantine== Although U.S. troops will not be assigned to provide care for Ebola patients, rigorous precautions to protect them from the virus will be put in place. On 17 October 2014, [[Marine Corps]] Maj. Gen. James Lariviere told Congress that “We have a no-touch policy and a three-foot separation rule with local nationals”…“A typical soldier’s day will be to get up, have their temperature taken, go out and perform whatever task they are there to do. They will only eat approved food and drink bottled water and wash their hands in chlorine solution. When they get back to their compounds, they will have their temperature taken and do a [[chlorine]] wash again.” The [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army]], [[Raymond T. Odierno]], ordered on October 27 a 21-day quarantine of all soldiers returning from Operation United Assistance. Up to 12 soldiers have been quarantined so far in a U.S. base in Italy.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/us-army-quarantine-troops-fighting-ebola/story?id=26486775|title=US Army to Quarantine Troops Who Were Fighting Ebola|last=Martinez|first=Luis|date=27 October 2014|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=8 November 2014}} == See also == *[[Expeditionary Medical Support System]] *[[Operation Unified Assistance]] (for the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]]) *[[Operation Unified Response]] (for the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|2014 West Africa Ebola outbreak}} *{{official website|http://www.africom.mil/operation-united-assistance}} *Center for Army Lessons Learned, [http://usacac.army.mil/sites/default/files/publications/16-05.pdf 16-05] *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/usarmyafrica/sets/72157648359150049/ Clearing the way for Ebola treatment unit sites] *[https://community.apan.org/apcn/ern Ebola Response] US DOD information sharing portal on the [[Defense Information Systems Agency|DISA]] UISS All Partner's Access Network ([https://www.apan.org APAN]) {{Filoviridae}} [[Category:West African Ebola virus epidemic]] [[Category:Health in Liberia]] [[Category:2014 in Liberia]] [[Category:2014 in the United States]] [[Category:Liberia–United States relations]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

Loizou''' (November 10, 1965 – July 22, 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/news/2012/7/25-18951_Cochlear-Implant-Pioneer-Professor-Lost-to-Cancer_article.html|title= Cochlear Implant Pioneer, Professor Lost to Cancer|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2012-11-27}}) was Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering (EE), [[University of Texas at Dallas academic programs#Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science|Erik Jonsson School of Engineering & Computer Science]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ee.utdallas.edu/|title= Erik Jonsson School of Engineering & Computer Science|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2012-11-27}} at the [[University of Texas at Dallas]] (UTD). == Career == Loizou was an assistant professor at the University of Arkansas, Little Rock (1996 to 1999) prior to joining the Erik Jonsson School of Engineering and Computer Science, where he helped co-found the Center of Robust Speech Systems (CRSS). He established the Speech Processing and Cochlear Implant Laboratories at the University of Texas at Dallas and held the Cecil and Ida Green Chair in the Department of Electrical Engineering since 2009. Loizou developed a noisy speech corpus known as NOIZEUS.{{cite web|url=http://www.utdallas.edu/~loizou/speech/noizeus/|title=NOIZEUS: A noisy speech corpus for evaluation of speech enhancement algorithms|publisher=University of Texas at Dallas|accessdate=2012-11-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630180754/http://www.utdallas.edu/~loizou/speech/noizeus/|archivedate=2012-06-30|df=}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.utdallas.edu/~loizou Philipos Loizou's Homepage] * [http://crss.utdallas.edu/~loizou/cimplants CI lab] * [http://crss.utdallas.edu/~loizou/speech Speech Processing lab] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loizou, Philipos C.}} [[Category:University of Texas at Dallas faculty]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Audiologists]] [[Category:Ira A. '''Ponnambalam Kumaraswamy''' (often referred to as Poondi Kumaraswamy) (1930 - 1988) was a leading [[hydrologist]] from [[India]].<ref>http://alberteinstein.info/vufind1/Record/EAR000021872 Catalogue details about a philosophical correspondence of Albert Einstein to Kumaraswamy when he was a young research engineer at Poondi</ref> He was elected a Fellow of the Indian Academy of Sciences in 1972<ref>http://www.ias.ac.in/describe/fellow/Kumaraswamy,__Ponnambalam list of Fellows of the Indian Academy of Sciences</ref> although his only formal education was a [[Civil Engineering]] Bachelor's degree from [[College of Engineering, Guindy]], [[University of Madras]]. Before his death in 1988, at 57 years old, he was the only one to have received both the Homi Bhabha Fellowship 1967-69 <ref>http://homibhabhafellowships.com/HomiBhabhaFellowsList.aspx Mr. P. Kumaraswamy</ref> (he spent his time at the [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]], Bombay, and at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], Cambridge, Massachusetts doing research in Groundwater modeling) and the [[Jawaharlal Nehru Fellowship]] 1975-77,<ref>http://www.jnmf.in/flist.html list of Jawaharlal Nehru Fellows</ref> two of the country's top research awards.
During the period of Jawaharlal Nehru Fellowship he created the first comprehensive 20 volume hydrological atlas of Tamil Nadu State of India including mathematical models, details of hydraulic structures, among others. He developed also the double bounded probability density function ([[Kumaraswamy distribution]]), a probability density function suitable for physical variables that are usually bounded. This distribution is in use in electrical, civil, mechanical, and financial engineering applications. He gave the first practical hard rock well theory<ref> ''Journal of Hydraulics Division'' (Vol 108(10), Oct 1982, pages 1194-1207) of the American Society of Civil Engineers for citation of his work on hard-rock well theory</ref> that won him the Gold Medal award from Indian Geohydrologists in 1974. He worked also as a design and construction engineer of two major industrial works, namely, the Tiruchirappalli Boiler Plant, and the Tuticorin Harbour Project. In addition he was involved in the hydraulic design of numerous dams, canals, and other hydraulic structures throughout South India.
He was also well known among many as a [[Periyar Ramasami]] follower even during the periods of emergency (1975) when many of Periyar's followers suffered, some even became afraid to associate with Periyar or his movements due to the atrocities created at that time on the followers. He was a member of the Periyar's rationalist movement and a close friend of [[K. Veeramani]].

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Seasonal affective disorder | synonyms = Winter depression, winter blues, summer depression, seasonal depression | image = File:Light Therapy for SAD.jpg | caption = Bright [[light therapy]] is a common treatment for seasonal affective disorder and for [[circadian rhythm sleep disorder]]s. | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = | Clinical significance = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Seasonal affective disorder''' ('''SAD''') is a [[mood disorder]] subset in which people who have normal [[mental health]] throughout most of the year exhibit [[depression (mood)|depressive]] symptoms at the same time each year, most commonly in the winter.<ref name="Oginska, Halszka 2014">{{cite journal | last1 = Oginska | first1 = Halszka | last2 = Oginska-Bruchal | first2 = Katarzyna | year = 2014 | title = Chronotype And Personality Factors Of Predisposition To Seasonal Affective Disorder | url = | journal = Chronobiology International: the Journal of Biological & Medical Rhythm Research | volume = 31 | issue = 4| pages = 523–531 | doi=10.3109/07420528.2013.874355}}</ref><ref>Ivry, Sara (August 13, 2002). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03E4DA103AF930A2575BC0A9649C8B63&sec=health Seasonal Depression can Accompany Summer Sun]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved September 6, 2008</ref> Common symptoms include, sleeping too much, having little to no energy, and overeating.<ref>{{MedlinePlusOverview|seasonalaffectivedisorder}}</ref> The condition in the summer can include heightened [[anxiety]].<ref name="mayoclinic.com">[http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/seasonal-affective-disorder/DS00195/DSECTION=2 Seasonal affective disorder (SAD): Symptoms]. MayoClinic.com (September 22, 2011). Retrieved on March 24, 2013.</ref>
<!-- Diagnosis --> In the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'' DSM-IV and [[DSM-5]], its status was changed. It is no longer classified as a unique mood disorder but is now a specifier, called "with seasonal pattern", for recurrent major depressive disorder that occurs at a specific time of the year and fully remits otherwise.<ref name="DSM-5-Bipolar and related disorders">{{Cite book| last= American Psychiatric Association| year= 2013| title=Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders| edition=Fifth| publisher=American Psychiatric Publishing| location=Arlington, VA| pages=123–154| isbn= 978-0-89042-555-8 }}</ref> Although experts were initially skeptical, this condition is now recognized as a common disorder.<ref>Friedman, Richard A. (December 18, 2007) [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/18/health/18mind.html?em&ex=1198213200&en=a955503f665508cf&ei=5087%0A Brought on by Darkness, Disorder Needs Light]. ''[[New York Times]]’’.</ref>
<!-- Epidemiology and history --> SAD in the United States affects from 1.4% in Florida to 9.9% in Alaska.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nolen-Hoeksema|first1=Susan|title=Abnormal Psychology|date=2014|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|location=New York, New York|isbn=978-1-259-06072-4|pages=179|edition=6th}}</ref> SAD was formally described and named in 1984 by [[Norman E. Rosenthal]] and colleagues at the [[National Institute of Mental Health]].<ref name="Rosenthal, NE 1984"> {{Cite journal | doi = 10.1001/archpsyc.1984.01790120076010 | last1 = Rosenthal | first1 = N. E. | last2 = Sack | first2 = D. A. | last3 = Gillin | first3 = J. C. | last4 = Lewy | first4 = A. J. | last5 = Goodwin | first5 = F. K. | last6 = Davenport | first6 = Y. | last7 = Mueller | first7 = P. S. | last8 = Newsome | first8 = D. A. | last9 = Wehr | first9 = T. A. | title = Seasonal affective disorder. A description of the syndrome and preliminary findings with light therapy | journal = Archives of General Psychiatry | volume = 41 | issue = 1 | pages = 72–80 | year = 1984 | pmid = 6581756| pmc = 2686645 }}</ref><ref name="Marshall2003">Marshall, Fiona. Cheevers, Peter (2003). "Positive options for Seasonal Affective Disorder", p. 77. Hunter House, Alameda, Calif. {{ISBN|0-89793-413-X}}.</ref>
==Signs and symptoms== SAD is a type of [[major depressive disorder]], and sufferers may exhibit any of the associated symptoms, such as feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness, thoughts of suicide, loss of interest in activities, withdrawal from social interaction, sleep and appetite problems, difficulty with concentrating and making decisions, decreased libido, a lack of energy, or agitation.<ref name="mayoclinic.com"/> Symptoms of winter SAD often include oversleeping or difficulty waking up in the morning, nausea, and a tendency to over eat, often with a craving for carbohydrates, which leads to weight gain.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Partonen |first1=Dr. Timo |title=Seasonal affective disorder |journal=The Lancet |date=1998 |volume=352 |issue=9137 |pages=1369–1374 |doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(98)01015-0}}</ref> SAD is typically associated with winter depression, but [[springtime lethargy]] or other seasonal mood patterns are not uncommon<ref>{{cite web|title=What is SAD (Seasonal Affective Disorder)?|url=http://sadlampsusa.com/articles/what-is-sad/|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>. Although each individual case is different, in contrast to winter SAD, people who experience spring and summer depression may be more likely to show symptoms such as insomnia, decreased appetite and weight loss, and agitation or anxiety.<ref name="mayoclinic.com"/>
===Bipolar disorder=== ''With seasonal pattern'' is a specifier for ''bipolar and related disorders'', including bipolar I disorder and bipolar II disorder.<ref name="DSM-5-Bipolar and related disorders"/> Most people with SAD experience [[major depressive disorder]], but as many as 20% may have a [[bipolar disorder]]. It is important to discriminate between diagnoses because there are important treatment differences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mooddisorderscanada.ca/documents/Consumer%20and%20Family%20Support/Depression.pdf |title= Depression |accessdate= August 8, 2009|format= PDF|publisher= Mood Disorders Society of Canada }}</ref> In these cases, people who have the ''With seasonal pattern'' specifier may experience a depressive episode either due to major depressive disorder or as part of bipolar disorder during the winter and remit in the summer.<ref name="DSM-5-Bipolar and related disorders"/> Around 25% of patients with [[bipolar disorder]] may present with a depressive seasonal pattern, which is associated with bipolar II disorder, rapid cycling, eating disorders, and more depressive episodes.<ref name="Geoffroy-2013">{{Cite journal |author1=Geoffroy PA |author2=Bellivier F |author3=Scott J |author4=Boudebesse C |author5=Lajnef M |author6=Gard S |author7=Kahn JP |author8=Azorin JM |author9=Henry C |author10=Leboyer M |author11=Etain B. | title = Bipolar Disorder with Seasonal Pattern: Clinical Characteristics and Gender Influences. | journal = Chronobiol Int. |date=Aug 2013 | doi = 10.3109/07420528.2013.800091 | pmid = 23931033 | volume=30 | issue=9 | pages=1101–7 | pmc=5225270}}</ref> Gender displays distinct clinical characteristics associated to seasonal pattern: males present with more Bipolar II disorder and a higher number of depressive episodes, and females with rapid cycling and eating disorders.<ref name="Geoffroy-2013"/>
==Cause== In many species, activity is diminished during the winter months in response to the reduction in available food, the reduction of [[sunlight]] (especially for [[diurnality|diurnal]] animals) and the difficulties of surviving in cold weather. [[Hibernation]] is an extreme example, but even species that do not hibernate often exhibit changes in behavior during the winter.<ref name="Nesse">{{Cite book|last1=Nesse|first1= Randolph M|authorlink1=Randolph M. Nesse|last2=Williams|first2=George C|authorlink2=George C. Williams (biologist)|title= Why We Get Sick|edition= First|publisher= Vintage Books|location= New York |isbn= 0812922247|year=1996 }}</ref> Presumably, food was scarce during most of [[human prehistory]], and a tendency toward low mood during the winter months would have been adaptive by reducing the need for calorie intake.<ref name="Kalbitzer, J 2013">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/s00213-013-3308-1| last1 = Kalbitzer | first1 = J. | last2 = Kalbitzer | first2 = U. | last3 = Moos Knudsen | first3 = G.| last4 = Cumming | first4 = P.| last5 = Heinz | first5 = A.| title = How the cerebral serotonin homeostasis predicts environmental changes: a model to explain seasonal changes of brain 5-HTT as intermediate phenotype of the 5-HTTLPR| journal = Psychopharmacology| volume = 230 | issue = 3| pages = 333–343| year = 2013 | pmid = 24150247}}</ref> The preponderance of women with SAD suggests that the response may also somehow regulate [[reproduction]].<ref name="Nesse"/>
Various proximate causes have been proposed. One possibility is that SAD is related to a lack of [[serotonin]], and [[serotonin polymorphism]]s could play a role in SAD,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Johansson | first1 = C. | last2 = Smedh | first2 = C. | last3 = Partonen | first3 = T. | last4 = Pekkarinen | first4 = P. | last5 = Paunio | first5 = T. | last6 = Ekholm | first6 = J. | last7 = Peltonen | first7 = L. | last8 = Lichtermann | first8 = D. | last9 = Palmgren | first9 = J. | last10 = Adolfsson | first10 = R. | last11 = Schalling | first11 = M. | title = Seasonal Affective Disorder and Serotonin-Related Polymorphisms | doi = 10.1006/nbdi.2000.0373 | journal = Neurobiology of Disease | volume = 8 | issue = 2 | pages = 351–357 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11300730 | pmc = }}</ref> although this has been disputed.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1017/S0033291703007372 | last1 = Johansson | first1 = C. | last2 = Willeit | first2 = M. | last3 = Levitan | first3 = R. | last4 = Partonen | first4 = T. | last5 = Smedh | first5 = C. | last6 = Del Favero | first6 = J. | last7 = Bel Kacem | first7 = S. | last8 = Praschak-Rieder | first8 = N. | last9 = Neumeister | first9 = A. | last10 = Masellis | first10 = M. | last11 = Basile | first11 = V. | last12 = Zill | first12 = P. | last13 = Bondy | first13 = B. | last14 = Paunio | first14 = T. | last15 = Kasper | first15 = S. | last16 = Van Broeckhoven | first16 = C. | last17 = Nilsson | first17 = L. -G. | last18 = Lam | first18 = R. | last19 = Schalling | first19 = M. | last20 = Adolfsson | first20 = R. | title = The serotonin transporter promoter repeat length polymorphism, seasonal affective disorder and seasonality | journal = Psychological Medicine | volume = 33 | issue = 5 | pages = 785–792 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12877393}}</ref> Mice incapable of turning serotonin into N-acetylserotonin (by [[serotonin N-acetyltransferase]]) appear to express "depression-like" behavior, and antidepressants such as [[fluoxetine]] increase the amount of the enzyme serotonin N-acetyltransferase, resulting in an antidepressant-like effect.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1034/j.1600-079X.2001.300305.x | last1 = Uz | first1 = T. | last2 = Manev | first2 = H. | title = Prolonged swim-test immobility of serotonin N-acetyltransferase (AANAT)-mutant mice | journal = Journal of Pineal Research | volume = 30 | issue = 3 | pages = 166–170 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11316327}}</ref> Another theory is that the cause may be related to [[melatonin]] which is produced in dim light and darkness by the [[pineal gland]],<ref name="search.proquest" /> since there are direct connections, via the [[retinohypothalamic tract]] and the [[suprachiasmatic nucleus]], between the retina and the pineal gland.{{Citation needed|date=November 2012}} Melatonin secretion is controlled by the endogenous circadian clock, but can also be suppressed by bright light.<ref name="search.proquest" />
One study looked at whether some people could be predisposed to SAD based on personality traits. Correlations between certain personality traits, higher levels of neuroticism, agreeableness, openness, and an avoidance-oriented coping style, appeared to be common in those with SAD.<ref name="Oginska, Halszka 2014"/>
==Diagnosis== According to the American Psychiatric Association [[DSM-IV]] criteria,<ref>{{Cite book|last=Gabbard |first=Glen O |title=Treatment of Psychiatric Disorders |edition=3rd |volume=2 |publisher= American Psychiatric Publishing |location= Washington, DC |page= 1296 }}</ref> Seasonal Affective Disorder is not regarded as a separate disorder. It is called a "course specifier" and may be applied as an added description to the pattern of [[major depressive episode]]s in patients with [[major depressive disorder]] or patients with [[bipolar disorder]].
The "Seasonal Pattern Specifier" must meet four criteria: depressive episodes at a particular time of the year; remissions or mania/hypomania at a characteristic time of year; these patterns must have lasted two years with no nonseasonal major depressive episodes during that same period; and these seasonal depressive episodes outnumber other depressive episodes throughout the patient's lifetime. The [[Mayo Clinic]]<ref name="mayoclinic.com"/> describes three types of SAD, each with its own set of symptoms.
==Pathophysiology== Seasonal mood variations are believed to be related to light. An argument for this view is the effectiveness of bright-[[light therapy]].<ref name = "Lam">{{Cite journal | last1 = Lam | first1 = R. W. | last2 = Levitt | first2 = A. J. | last3 = Levitan | first3 = R. D. | last4 = Enns | first4 = M. W. | last5 = Morehouse | first5 = R. | last6 = Michalak | first6 = E. E. | last7 = Tam | first7 = E. M. | doi = 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.5.805 | title = The Can-SAD Study: A Randomized Controlled Trial of the Effectiveness of Light Therapy and Fluoxetine in Patients with Winter Seasonal Affective Disorder | journal = American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 163 | issue = 5 | pages = 805–812 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16648320 | pmc = }}</ref> SAD is measurably present at latitudes in the [[Arctic circle|Arctic region]], such as northern [[Finland]] (64°00′N), where the rate of SAD is 9.5%.<ref name = "Avery">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0006-3223(01)01200-8 | last1 = Avery | first1 = D. H. | last2 = Eder | first2 = D. N. | last3 = Bolte | first3 = M. A. | last4 = Hellekson | first4 = C. J. | last5 = Dunner | first5 = D. L. | last6 = Vitiello | first6 = M. V. | last7 = Prinz | first7 = P. N. | title = Dawn simulation and bright light in the treatment of SAD: A controlled study | journal = Biological Psychiatry | volume = 50 | issue = 3 | pages = 205–216 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11513820}}</ref> Cloud cover may contribute to the negative effects of SAD.<ref name = "Modell">{{Cite journal | last1 = Modell | first1 = J. G. | last2 = Rosenthal | first2 = N. E. | last3 = Harriett | first3 = A. E. | last4 = Krishen | first4 = A. | last5 = Asgharian | first5 = A. | last6 = Foster | first6 = V. J. | last7 = Metz | first7 = A. | last8 = Rockett | first8 = C. B. | last9 = Wightman | first9 = D. S. | doi = 10.1016/j.biopsych.2005.07.021 | title = Seasonal Affective Disorder and Its Prevention by Anticipatory Treatment with Bupropion XL | journal = Biological Psychiatry | volume = 58 | issue = 8 | pages = 658–667 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16271314 | pmc = }}</ref> There is evidence that many patients with SAD have [[Delayed sleep phase disorder|a delay]] in their [[circadian rhythm]], and that bright light treatment corrects these delays which may be responsible for the improvement in patients.<ref name="search.proquest">{{Cite journal | last1 = Lam | first1 = R. W. | last2 = Levitan | first2 = R. D. | title = Pathophysiology of seasonal affective disorder: A review | journal = Journal of psychiatry & neuroscience : JPN | volume = 25 | issue = 5 | pages = 469–480 | year = 2000 | pmid = 11109298 | pmc = 1408021}}</ref>
The symptoms of it mimic those of [[dysthymia]] or even [[major depressive disorder]]. There is also potential risk of suicide in some patients experiencing SAD. One study reports 6–35% of sufferers required hospitalization during one period of illness.<ref name = "Modell"/> At times, patients may not feel depressed, but rather lack energy to perform everyday activities.<ref name = "Lam"/>
Subsyndromal Seasonal Affective Disorder is a milder form of SAD experienced by an estimated 14.3% (vs. 6.1% SAD) of the U.S. population.<ref name = "Avery2">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1034/j.1600-0447.2001.00078.x | last1 = Avery | first1 = D. H. | last2 = Kizer | first2 = D. | last3 = Bolte | first3 = M. A. | last4 = Hellekson | first4 = C. | title = Bright light therapy of subsyndromal seasonal affective disorder in the workplace: Morning vs. Afternoon exposure | journal = Acta Psychiatrica Scandinavica | volume = 103 | issue = 4 | pages = 267–274 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11328240}}</ref> The blue feeling experienced by both SAD and SSAD sufferers can usually be dampened or extinguished by exercise and increased outdoor activity, particularly on sunny days, resulting in increased solar exposure.<ref name = "Leppämäki">{{Cite journal | last1 = Leppämäki | first1 = S. | last2 = Haukka | first2 = J. | last3 = Lönnqvist | first3 = J. | last4 = Partonen | first4 = T. | title = Drop-out and mood improvement: A randomised controlled trial with light exposure and physical exercise ISRCTN36478292 | journal = BMC Psychiatry | volume = 4 | pages = 22 | doi = 10.1186/1471-244X-4-22 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15306031 | pmc =514552 }}</ref> Connections between human mood, as well as energy levels, and the seasons are well documented, even in healthy individuals.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Partonen|first1=Timo|last2=Lönnqvist|first2=Jouko|title=Bright light improves vitality and alleviates distress in healthy people|journal=Journal of Affective Disorders|date=2000|volume=57|issue=1–3|pages=55–61|doi=10.1016/S0165-0327(99)00063-4|pmid=10708816}}</ref>
==Management== [[Image:Light Therapy Lamp.jpg|thumb|One type of light therapy lamp]] {{See also|Occupational therapy in the management of seasonal affective disorder}} Treatments for classic (winter-based) seasonal affective disorder include [[light therapy]], medication, [[Negative air ionization therapy|ionized-air administration]],<ref name="Terman" /> [[cognitive-behavioral therapy]] and carefully timed supplementation<ref name="ohsu.edu">{{Cite journal | last1 = Bhattacharjee | first1 = Y. | title = Is Internal Timing Key to Mental Health? | doi = 10.1126/science.317.5844.1488 | journal = Science | volume = 317 | issue = 5844 | pages = 1488–1490 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17872420| pmc = }}</ref> of the hormone [[melatonin]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nimh.nih.gov/news/science-news/2006/properly-timed-light-melatonin-lift-winter-depression-by-syncing-rhythms.shtml|title=Properly Timed Light, Melatonin Lift Winter Depression by Syncing Rhythms |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1 May 2006 |website=NIMH Science News|publisher=The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) |accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>
Photoperiod-related alterations of the duration of melatonin secretion may affect the seasonal mood cycles of SAD. This suggests that light therapy may be an effective treatment for SAD.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.3928/02793695-20090101-07 | last1 = Howland | first1 = R. H. | title = Somatic therapies for seasonal affective disorder | journal = Journal of psychosocial nursing and mental health services | volume = 47 | issue = 1 | pages = 17–20 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19227105}}</ref> Light therapy uses a [[light therapy|lightbox]] which emits far more [[Lumen (unit)|lumens]] than a customary incandescent lamp. Bright white [[Full-spectrum light|"full spectrum"]] light at 10,000 lux, blue light at a wavelength of 480 nm at 2,500 lux or green (actually cyan or blue-green<ref>{{cite web|author=Zimmerman Jones, Andrew |title=The Visible Light Spectrum |url=http://physics.about.com/od/lightoptics/a/vislightspec.htm |date=February 15, 2012}}</ref>) light at a wavelength of 500 nm at 350 lux are used, with the first-mentioned historically preferred.<ref name = "Saeeduddin">{{Cite journal| year=1995 |title=Phase Response Curve of Low-Intensity Green Light in Winter Depressives|doi=10.1186/1471-244X-5-42 |volume=24 |page=508 |journal=Sleep Research |quote= "The magnitude of the phase shifts [using low-level green light therapy] are comparable to those obtained using high-intensity white light in winter-depressives." | author = Saeeduddin Ahmed, Neil L Cutter, Alfred J. Lewy, Vance K. Bauer, Robert L Sack and Mary S. Cardoza }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Strong | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Marchant | first2 = B. K. | last3 = Reimherr | first3 = F. W. | last4 = Williams | first4 = E. | last5 = Soni | first5 = P. | last6 = Mestas | first6 = R. | doi = 10.1002/da.20538 | title = Narrow-band blue-light treatment of seasonal affective disorder in adults and the influence of additional nonseasonal symptoms | journal = Depression and Anxiety | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 273–278 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19016463 | pmc = }}</ref>
Bright light therapy is effective<ref name = "Avery2"/> with the patient sitting a prescribed distance, commonly 30–60 cm, in front of the box with her/his eyes open but not staring at the light source<ref name = "Avery"/> for 30–60 minutes. A study published in May 2010 suggests that the blue light often used for SAD treatment should perhaps be replaced by green or white illumination.<ref name="doi101126">{{Cite journal | last1 = Gooley | first1 = J. J. | last2 = Rajaratnam | first2 = S. M. W. | last3 = Brainard | first3 = G. C. | last4 = Kronauer | first4 = R. E. | last5 = Czeisler | first5 = C. A. | last6 = Lockley | first6 = S. W. | doi = 10.1126/scitranslmed.3000741 | title = Spectral Responses of the Human Circadian System Depend on the Irradiance and Duration of Exposure to Light | journal = Science Translational Medicine | volume = 2 | issue = 31 | pages = 31ra33 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20463367 | pmc = 4414925}}</ref> Discovering the best schedule is essential. One study has shown that up to 69% of patients find lightbox treatment inconvenient and as many as 19% stop use because of this.<ref name = "Avery"/>
[[Dawn simulation]] has also proven to be effective; in some studies, there is an 83% better response when compared to other bright light therapy.<ref name = "Avery"/> When compared in a study to [[negative air ionization therapy|negative air ionization]], bright light was shown to be 57% effective vs. dawn simulation 50%.<ref name = "Terman">{{Cite journal | last1 = Terman | first1 = M. | last2 = Terman | first2 = J. S. | doi = 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.12.2126 | title = Controlled Trial of Naturalistic Dawn Simulation and Negative Air Ionization for Seasonal Affective Disorder | journal = American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 163 | issue = 12 | pages = 2126–33 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17151164| pmc = }}</ref> Patients using light therapy can experience improvement during the first week, but increased results are evident when continued throughout several weeks.<ref name = "Avery"/> Most studies have found it effective without use year round but rather as a seasonal treatment lasting for several weeks until frequent light exposure is naturally obtained.<ref name = "Lam"/>
[[Light therapy]] can also consist of exposure to sunlight, either by spending more time outside<ref>Beck, Melinda. (December 1, 2009) [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703300504574567881192085174?mod=rss_Today%27s_Most_Popular "Bright Ideas for Treating the Winter Blues"]. (Section title: "Exercise outdoors") ''The Wall Street Journal''.</ref> or using a computer-controlled [[heliostat]] to reflect sunlight into the windows of a home or office.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.practicalsolar.com/applications.html | title = Applications: Health | accessdate = June 9, 2009 | publisher = Practical Solar | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090615153220/http://www.practicalsolar.com/applications.html | archivedate = June 15, 2009 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newyorkhousemagazine.com/pages/full_story?page_label=home_main_top&id=2631630&widget=push&instance=home_green_future&article-Grab%20the%20Sun%20With%20Heliostats%20=&open=& | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091004205721/http://www.newyorkhousemagazine.com/pages/full_story?page_label=home_main_top&id=2631630&widget=push&instance=home_green_future&article-Grab%20the%20Sun%20With%20Heliostats%20=&open=& | dead-url = yes | archive-date = October 4, 2009 | title = Grab the Sun With Heliostats | publisher = New York House | accessdate = December 8, 2009 | date = June 1, 2009 }}</ref> Although light therapy is the leading treatment for seasonal affective disorder, prolonged direct sunlight or artificial lights that don't block the ultraviolet range should be avoided due to the threat of [[skin cancer]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Osborn | first1 = J. | last2 = Raetz | first2 = J. | last3 = Kost | first3 = A. | year = 2014 | title = Seasonal Affective Disorder, Grief Reaction, and Adjustment Disorder | url = | journal = Medical Clinics of North America| volume = 98 | issue = 5| pages = 1065–1077 | doi = 10.1016/j.mcna.2014.06.006 }}</ref>
[[SSRI]] (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants have proven effective in treating SAD.<ref name = "Modell"/> Effective antidepressants are [[fluoxetine]], [[sertraline]], or [[paroxetine]].<ref name = "Lam"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Moscovitch | first1 = A. | last2 = Blashko | first2 = C. A. | last3 = Eagles | first3 = J. M. | last4 = Darcourt | first4 = G. | last5 = Thompson | first5 = C. | last6 = Kasper | first6 = S. | last7 = Lane | first7 = R. M. | author8 = International Collaborative Group on Sertraline in the Treatment of Outpatients with Seasonal Affective Disorders | doi = 10.1007/s00213-003-1594-8 | title = A placebo-controlled study of sertraline in the treatment of outpatients with seasonal affective disorder | journal = Psychopharmacology | volume = 171 | issue = 4 | pages = 390–397 | year = 2004 | pmid = 14504682 | pmc = }}</ref> Both fluoxetine and light therapy are 67% effective in treating SAD according to direct head-to-head trials conducted during the 2006 Can-SAD study.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Lam | first = Raymond W. | author2 = Anthony J. Levitt | author3 = Robert D. Levitan | date = May 2006 | title = The Can-SAD Study: A Randomized Controlled Trial of the Effectiveness of Light Therapy and Fluoxetine in Patients With Winter Seasonal Affective Disorder | journal = Am J Psychiatry | volume = 163 | issue = 5 | pmid = 16648320 | pages = 805–812 | url = http://day-lights.com/light-therapy-news/downloads/can-sad-study-wp.pdf | format = PDF | doi = 10.1176/appi.ajp.163.5.805 | display-authors = etal | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5sSzQgPfj?url=http://day-lights.com/light-therapy-news/downloads/can-sad-study-wp.pdf | archivedate = September 3, 2010 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Subjects using the light therapy protocol showed earlier clinical improvement, generally within one week of beginning the clinical treatment.<ref name = "Lam"/> [[Bupropion]] extended-release has been shown to prevent SAD for one in eight people, but has not been compared directly to other preventive options in trials.<ref name="Gartlehner 2015">{{cite journal|last1=Gartlehner|first1=Gerald|title=Second-generation antidepressants for preventing seasonal affective disorder in adults.|journal=Cochrane Database Syst Rev|date=2015|issue=11|pmid=26558418|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0079539/|accessdate=19 November 2015|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD011268.pub2|volume=11|pages=CD011268|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
[[Air ioniser|Negative air ionization]], which involves releasing charged particles into the sleep environment, has been found effective with a 47.9% improvement if the negative ions are in sufficient density (quantity).<ref name="Terman" /><ref name="doi 10.1001/archpsyc.55.10.875">{{Cite journal | last1 = Terman | first1 = M. | last2 = Terman | first2 = J. | last3 = Ross | first3 = D. | doi = 10.1001/archpsyc.55.10.875 | title = A Controlled Trial of Timed Bright Light and Negative Air Ionization for Treatment of Winter Depression | journal = Archives of General Psychiatry | volume = 55 | issue = 10 | pages = 875–82 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9783557| pmc = }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1089/acm.1995.1.87 | last1 = Terman | first1 = M. | last2 = Terman | first2 = J. S. | title = Treatment of seasonal affective disorder with a high-output negative ionizer | journal = Journal of alternative and complementary medicine | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 87–92 | year = 1995 | pmid = 9395604}}</ref>
Depending upon the patient, one treatment (e.g., lightbox) may be used in conjunction with another (e.g., medication).<ref name = "Lam"/>
[[Modafinil]] may be an effective and well-tolerated treatment in patients with seasonal affective disorder/winter depression.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lundt | first1 = L. | title = Modafinil treatment in patients with seasonal affective disorder/winter depression: An open-label pilot study | doi = 10.1016/S0165-0327(03)00162-9 | journal = Journal of Affective Disorders | volume = 81 | issue = 2 | pages = 173–178 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15306145 | pmc = }}</ref>
Another explanation is that [[vitamin D]] levels are too low when people do not get enough [[Ultraviolet#Vitamin D|Ultraviolet-B on their skin]]. An alternative to using bright lights is to take vitamin D supplements.<ref>[http://newfoundlandnews.blogspot.com/2008/01/sadness-seasonal-affective-disorder.html SADness: Seasonal Affective Disorder & Vitamin D]. newfoundlandnews.blogspot.com (January 27, 2008)</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wilkins | first1 = C. H. | last2 = Sheline | first2 = Y. I. | last3 = Roe | first3 = C. M. | last4 = Birge | first4 = S. J. | last5 = Morris | first5 = J. C. | title = Vitamin D Deficiency is Associated with Low Mood and Worse Cognitive Performance in Older Adults | doi = 10.1097/01.JGP.0000240986.74642.7c | journal = American Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry | volume = 14 | issue = 12 | pages = 1032–1040 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17138809 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/s002130050517 | last1 = Lansdowne | first1 = A. T. | last2 = Provost | first2 = S. C. | title = Vitamin D3 enhances mood in healthy subjects during winter | journal = Psychopharmacology | volume = 135 | issue = 4 | pages = 319–323 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9539254}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gloth Fm | first1 = 3. | last2 = Alam | first2 = W. | last3 = Hollis | first3 = B. | title = Vitamin D vs broad spectrum phototherapy in the treatment of seasonal affective disorder | journal = The Journal of Nutrition, Health & Aging | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 5–7 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10888476}}</ref> However, studies did not show a link between vitamin D levels and depressive symptoms in elderly Chinese<ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/03/090317142847.htm "Vitamin D May Not Be The Answer To Feeling SAD"]. sciencedaily.com (March 2009)</ref> nor among elderly British women.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Dumville | first1 = J. C. | last2 = Miles | first2 = J. N. | last3 = Porthouse | first3 = J. | last4 = Cockayne | first4 = S. | last5 = Saxon | first5 = L. | last6 = King | first6 = C. | title = Can vitamin D supplementation prevent winter-time blues? A randomised trial among older women | journal = The Journal of Nutrition, Health & Aging | volume = 10 | issue = 2 | pages = 151–153 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16554952}}</ref>
[[Physical exercise]] has shown to be an effective form of depression therapy, particularly when in addition to another form of treatment for SAD.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0165-1781(00)00138-4 | last1 = Pinchasov | first1 = B. B. | last2 = Shurgaja | first2 = A. M. | last3 = Grischin | first3 = O. V. | last4 = Putilov | first4 = A. A. | title = Mood and energy regulation in seasonal and non-seasonal depression before and after midday treatment with physical exercise or bright light | journal = Psychiatry Research | volume = 94 | issue = 1 | pages = 29–42 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10788675}}</ref> One particular study noted marked effectiveness for treatment of depressive symptoms when combining regular exercise with bright light therapy.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0165-0327(01)00417-7 | last1 = Leppämäki | first1 = S. | last2 = Partonen | first2 = T. | last3 = Lönnqvist | first3 = J. | title = Bright-light exposure combined with physical exercise elevates mood | journal = Journal of Affective Disorders | volume = 72 | issue = 2 | pages = 139–144 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12200204}}</ref> Patients exposed to exercise which had been added to their treatments in 20 minutes intervals on the aerobic bike during the day along with the same amount of time underneath the [[UV light]] were seen to make quick recovery.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Roecklein | first1 = K. A. | last2 = Rohan | first2 = K. J. | title = Seasonal affective disorder: An overview and update | journal = Psychiatry (Edgmont (Pa. : Township)) | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 20–26 | year = 2005 | pmid = 21179639 | pmc = 3004726}}</ref>
==Epidemiology==
===Nordic countries=== Winter depression is a common slump in the mood of some inhabitants of most of the [[Nordic countries]]. It was first described by the 6th century [[Goths|Goth]] scholar [[Jordanes]] in his ''[[Getica]]'' wherein he described the inhabitants of [[Scandza]] (Scandinavia).<ref>Jordanes, ''Getica,'' ed. Mommsen, ''Mon. Germanae historica, V,'' Berlin, 1882.</ref> Iceland, however, seems to be an exception. A study of more than 2000 people there found the prevalence of seasonal affective disorder and seasonal changes in anxiety and depression to be unexpectedly ''low'' in both sexes.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1176/appi.ajp.157.2.234 | last1 = Magnusson | first1 = A. | last2 = Axelsson | first2 = J. | last3 = Karlsson | first3 = M. M. | last4 = Oskarsson | first4 = H. | title = Lack of seasonal mood change in the Icelandic population: Results of a cross-sectional study | journal = The American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 157 | issue = 2 | pages = 234–238 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10671392}}</ref> The study's authors suggested that propensity for SAD may differ due to some genetic factor within the Icelandic population. A study of Canadians of wholly Icelandic descent also showed low levels of SAD.<ref name="pmid8250680">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1001/archpsyc.1993.01820240031004 | last1 = Magnússon | first1 = A. | last2 = Axelsson | first2 = J. | title = The prevalence of seasonal affective disorder is low among descendants of Icelandic emigrants in Canada | journal = Archives of General Psychiatry | volume = 50 | issue = 12 | pages = 947–951 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8250680}}</ref> It has more recently been suggested that this may be attributed to the large amount of fish traditionally eaten by Icelandic people, in 2007 about 90 kilograms per person per year as opposed to about 24 kg in the US and Canada,<ref name=fao>[ftp://ftp.fao.org/FI/CDrom/CD_yearbook_2008/root/food_balance/section2.pdf Fishery and Aquaculture Statistics: SECTION 2 – Food balance sheets and fish contribution to protein supply, by country from 1961 to 2007]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} . Rome: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2008)</ref> rather than to genetic predisposition; a similar anomaly is noted in Japan, where annual fish consumption in recent years averages about 60 kg per capita.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1176/appi.ajp.158.2.328 | last1 = Cott | first1 = J. | last2 = Hibbeln | first2 = J. R. | title = Lack of seasonal mood change in Icelanders | journal = The American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 158 | issue = 2 | pages = 328 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11156835}}</ref> Fish are high in [[vitamin D]]. Fish also contain [[docosahexaenoic acid]] (DHA), which help with a variety of neurological dysfunctions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Horrocks |first1=Lloyd A.|last2=Yeo|first2=Young K.|title=Health Benefits of Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA)|journal=Pharmacological Research|date=September 1999|volume=40|issue=3|pages=211–225 |doi=10.1006/phrs.1999.0495}}</ref>
===Other countries=== In the United States, a diagnosis of seasonal affective disorder was first proposed by [[Norman E. Rosenthal]], M.D. in 1984. Rosenthal wondered why he became sluggish during the winter after moving from sunny South Africa to (cloudy in winter) [[New York (state)|New York]]. He started experimenting increasing exposure to artificial light, and found this made a difference. In [[Alaska]] it has been established that there is a SAD rate of 8.9%, and an even greater rate of 24.9%<ref>[http://www.britebox.co.uk/sad-study.php?page=latitude SAD Treatment | SAD Lamp | SAD Light | SAD Cure | Seasonal Affected Disorder Britebox Energise Case Study] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810084450/http://www.britebox.co.uk/sad-study.php?page=latitude |date=August 10, 2011 }}. Britebox.co.uk. Retrieved on March 24, 2013.</ref> for subsyndromal SAD.
Around 20% of Irish people are affected by SAD, according to a survey conducted in 2007. The survey also shows women are more likely to be affected by SAD than men.<ref>[http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/mhmhojididid/ One in five suffers from SAD]. BreakingNews.ie (November 10, 2007). Retrieved on March 24, 2013.</ref> An estimated 10% of the population in the Netherlands suffer from SAD.<ref>van der Sman (October 28, 2004) [http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10165/Stijl/Gezondheid-Gezin/Gezin/Donkere-dagen-Winterdepressie-verklaard.htm/ Donkere dagen: Winterdepressie verklaard]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Elsevier.nl. Retrieved on March 24, 2013.</ref>
==History== SAD was first systematically reported and named in the early 1980s by Norman E. Rosenthal, M.D., and his associates at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). Rosenthal was initially motivated by his desire to discover the cause of his own experience of depression during the dark days of the northern US winter. He theorized that the reduction in available natural light during winter was the cause. Rosenthal and his colleagues then documented the phenomenon of SAD in a placebo-controlled study utilizing light therapy.<ref name="Rosenthal, NE 1984"/><ref name="Marshall2003" /> A paper based on this research was published in 1984. Although Rosenthal's ideas were initially greeted with skepticism, SAD has become well recognized, and his 1993 book, ''Winter Blues''<ref>{{cite book |last=Rosenthal |first1=Norman E. |authorlink=Norman E. Rosenthal|title=Winter Blues: Everything You Need to Know to Beat Seasonal Affective Disorder|edition=Revised |location=New York |publisher=The Guilford Press |isbn=978-1593852146 |year=2006 }}</ref> has become the standard introduction to the subject.<ref>{{cite news |last=More |first=Lee Kremis |title=It's Wintertime: When Winter Falls, Many Find Themselves In Need Of Light |work=Milwaukee Sentinel |publisher= Gannett News Service |date=December 26, 1994 }}</ref>
Research on SAD in the United States began in 1979 when Herb Kern, a research engineer, had also noticed that he felt depressed during the winter months. Kern suspected that scarcer light in winter was the cause and discussed the idea with scientists at the NIMH who were working on bodily rhythms. They were intrigued, and responded by devising a lightbox to treat Kern’s depression. Kern felt much better within a few days of treatments, as did other patients treated in the same way.<ref name="Marshall2003" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Ban |first1=Thomas A. |title=An Oral History of Neuropsychopharmacology, The First Fifty Years, Peer Interviews |volume=5 |editor-last=Gershon |editor-first=Samuel |publisher=American College of Neuropsychopharmacology |year=2011 }}</ref>
It has also been suggested that SAD affects risky behavior, and those affected by SAD are more likely to opt for conservative investments, whether financially or scientifically.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lozano | first1 = G. A. | year = 2015 | title = SAD effects on grantsmanship | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/wol1/doi/10.1002/bies.201400165/full | journal = BioEssays | volume = 37 | issue = 1| pages = 10–11 | doi=10.1002/bies.201400165| arxiv = 1409.2924 }}</ref>

Hassan]] | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies|IFRC]] | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|http://www.bishacas-srcs.org}} | remarks = }} The '''Somali Red Crescent Society''' (SRCS) is a non-political, independent humanitarian organization in [[Somalia]] and is part of the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement]]. == History == The society was established in April 1963 through the Presidential Decree No. 187 in 1965.[http://www.bishacas-srcs.org/index.php The Somali Red Crescent Society], Retrieved 24 February 2012 In 1969, it was formally recognized by the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC) and became a member of the [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]] == Main programs and activities == === Healthcare === ==== Outpatient and mobile clinics ==== Since 1991, SRCS has been providing health services to the people of Somalia through a system of 62 Maternal and Child Health Outpatient (MCH/OPD) clinics and 4 mobile clinics,[http://bishacas-srcs.org/downloads/srcs_strategic_%20plan.pdf Somali Red Crescent Society Strategic Plan 2010 - 2014], Retrieved 24 February 2012 targeting vulnerable groups in the community such as mothers, children and wounded individuals. These permanent and mobile clinics are designed to serve the immediate neighborhood communities and remote villages respectively, with a focus on reducing mortality and morbidity. In 2009, 623,342 patients benefitted from the treatments offered in total. ==== Rehabilitation programmes ==== The SRCS rehabilitation programmes provide health care services to the physically disabled in Somalia through its 3 rehabilitation centers which are located in Mogadishu, Hargeisa and Galkayo respectively.[http://www.bishacas-srcs.org/blocks/s_rehab.php REHABILITATION SERVICES FOR THE PHYSICALLY DISABLED], Retrieved 24 February 2012 [[Prosthetics|Prosthesis]] and [[orthotics|orthosis]] appliances are produced in the workshops of these centers, with physiotherapy departments that offer physiotherapy treatment. In 2009, 429 orthoses and 534 prostheses were produced while 1924 persons received physiotherapy treatment. ==== Keysaney Teaching Hospital ==== Keysaney is one of the largest surgical hospitals in Somalia which focuses on trauma, surgery including electives and referrals from Mogadishu and the other cities of the country. Keysaney functions as the main teaching hospital in surgery and trauma for residents, interns and students in Somalia. The hospital is Located in Mogadishu, the capital city and was established in 1992, the hospital assisted thousands of weapon and non weapon wounded patients since the outbreak of the [[Somalia Civil War|civil war]]. Support is rendered by the ICRC in the form of payment of salaries and providing medicines and medical equipment through the SRCS. During 2009, 3856 were admitted in the hospital, of which 2361 weapon were wounded patients. ==== HIV and AIDS program ==== As of 2006, 44,000 Somalis were estimated to be infected with HIV, which is around 0.9% of the population.[http://www.ifrc.org/Docs/Appeals/annual08/MAA64006SO.pdf INTEGRATED HIV AND AIDS PROGRAMME 2008-2010], Retrieved 24 February 2012 The HIV and AIDS program initiated by the SRCS focuses on prevention, treatment, care and support throughout the country. There was great emphasis on changing the behavior of the sexually active cohort by promoting safe sex practices, voluntary testing and counselling. In 2009, awareness sessions were conducted by the SRCS HIV staff and volunteers to educate the communities on the risk of HIV infections. 127,000 people benefited from the sessions in total. ==== WatSan programme ==== The water and sanitation project is a collaboration between the SRCS and [[German Red Cross]] which targets the rural population in Somalia. The aim of the project is to increase the availability of safe water for human consumption, livestock and agriculture so as to meet the basic needs of the target population. Shallow wells and piped water systems were constructed to manage water supply while family latrines were built for improved sanitation. Water filters were given to communities using unsafe surface waters to ensure safe consumption. The total number direct and indirect beneficiaries was 3825 and 22,950 respectively.[http://www.bishacas-srcs.org/blocks/s_water.php WATER AND SANITATION], Retrieved 24 February 2012 == See also == * [[Somalia]] * [[List of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]] == References == == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.bishacas-srcs.org/index.php}} {{Red Cross Red Crescent Movement}} [[Category:Red Cross and Red Crescent national societies]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations in Somalia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1963]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Somalia]]
